While some kanji/radicals are âŸ®pictographs/ideographsâŸ¯, most aren't. Since most kanji are phonosemantic compounds, not all radicals contribute to the meaning of the kanji. Most kanji can become radicals in even bigger kanji. âŸ®ã€€å½¢ï¼ˆã‘ã„ï¼‰ã€€å£°ï¼ˆã›ã„ï¼‰(ã€€æ–‡ï¼ˆã‚‚ï¼‰ã€€å­—ï¼ˆã˜ï¼‰)âŸ¯|âŸ®phonosemantic compoundâŸ¯ Where does ã€€ é¤¨ <rp>(</rp><rt class="force">ã‹ã‚“ï¼‰ get its reading from? <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®å®˜âŸ¯ The vast majority of chinese characters are what kind? <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®Phono-semantic compoundsâŸ¯ The semantic component of a phono-semantic compound is known as a... <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®determinativeâŸ¯ Since ã€€ é¤¨ <rp>(</rp><rt class="force">ã‹ã‚“ï¼‰ get its reading from å®˜ and its meaning (mostly) from é£Ÿ, that makes it what in japanese terminology? <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®ã€€å½¢ï¼ˆã‘ã„ï¼‰ã€€å£°ï¼ˆã›ã„ï¼‰(ã€€æ–‡ï¼ˆã‚‚ï¼‰ã€€å­—ï¼ˆã˜ï¼‰)âŸ¯ Phono-semantic compound characters contain what, besides a semantic component? <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®a phonetic componentâŸ¯ Phono-semantic compound characters contain what, besides a phonetic component? <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®A semantic componentâŸ¯ How often can phono-semantic compounding occur on the same item? <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®RecursivevlyâŸ¯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> åŠ‡ (è±¦ = è™ + è±•, åŠ‡ = åˆ‚ + è±¦). </div> </div> How much meaning does the phonetic element of a phono-semantic compound contribute most often? <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®Often, at least a littleâŸ¯ What are æ—, æ£®, ä¼‘, ä¿¡, æ˜ examples for? <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®Compound IdeogramsâŸ¯ Compound ideogram characters are made up of 2 or more... <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®Idea- or pictographsâŸ¯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> yes, even despite the name </div> </div> Chinese characters made up of two or more ideo/pictograms are called (in english) <span class="divider">-></span> âŸ®Compound ideogramsâŸ¯

((h:all;::âœ«sm_favordiag.gifâœ«))<p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">   Japanese has <span class="c1-cloze">two distinct verbs</span> for <span class="c2-cloze">giving</span>, <span class="group-before-hide">depending on <span class="c3-cloze">who is giving to whom</span></span>:    <span class="c1-3-scr">     <span class="c6-7-hide line"><span class="c4-cloze">ã‚ã’ã‚‹</span> is <span class="c5-cloze">giving from the perspecitve of the giver</span>,</span>     <span class="c4-5-hide line"><span class="c6-cloze">ãã‚Œã‚‹</span> is <span class="c7-cloze">from the perspective of the reciever (but stil means to give, not to recieve)</span>,</span>     <span class="all-hide c8-show">this applies in <span class="c8-cloze">all gramattical persons (1, 2 and 3)</span>.</span>      <span class="c4-8-hide">The word for <span class="c9-cloze">recieving</span> has <span class="c10-cloze">no such distinction</span>, it is <span class="c11-cloze">ã‚‚ã‚‰ã†</span>. <span class="c11-14-scr">You don't <span class="c12-cloze">use this so often</span> when <span class="c13-cloze">describing other people</span>. Appropriate particles are <span class="c14-cloze">ã‹ã‚‰</span> and <span class="c14-cloze">ã«</span>.</span></span>   </span> </p> <p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">Examples:    <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">ã“ã‚Œã¯å…ˆç”Ÿã«<span class="c15-cloze">ã‚ã’ã‚‹</span> "<span class="c16-cloze">Iâ€™ll give this to teacher.</span>"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">å­¦ç”ŸãŒã“ã‚Œã‚’å…ˆç”Ÿã«<span class="c17-cloze">ã‚ã’ã‚‹</span>ã€‚â€<span class="c19-scr"><span class="c18-cloze">The student give this to teacher.</span></span> (<span class="c18-scr">looking at it from <span class="c19-cloze">the studentâ€™s point of view</span></span>)"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">åƒå††ã‚’è²¸ã—ã¦<span class="c20-cloze">ãã‚Œã‚‹ or ã‚‚ã‚‰ãˆã‚‹</span>ï¼Ÿ "<span class="c21-cloze">Will you give me the favor of lending 1000 yen?</span>"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">ãã‚Œã‚’ãã‚Œã‚‹ï¼Ÿ "<span class="c22-cloze">Can you give me that?</span>"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">å…ˆç”ŸãŒã“ã‚Œã‚’å­¦ç”Ÿã«<span class="c23-cloze">ãã‚Œã‚‹</span>ã€‚"<span class="c24-cloze">The teacher give this to student. (looking at it from the studentâ€™s point of view)</span>"</span> </p> <p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">   When <span class="c25-cloze">using a verb</span> (â‰ˆ <span class="c25-scr"><span class="c26-cloze">giving a favor</span></span>), the grammar is <span class="c27-cloze">ã¦+verb</span> (<span class="c27-cloze">ã¦ã‚ã’ã‚‹ãƒ»ã¦ãã‚Œã‚‹ãƒ»ã¦ã‚‚ã‚‰ã†</span>).    <span class="all-hide c28-33-unhide">When <span class="c28-cloze">asking for a favor / requesting something</span>, {{29::ã‚‚ã‚‰ã† becomes ã‚‚ã‚‰ãˆã‚‹ (so ã¦ã‚‚ã‚‰ãˆã‚‹)}} (but {{30::not in other cases}}).</span>   <span class="all-hide c31-33-unhide">ã¦ã‚‚ã‚‰ãˆã‚‹ can also mean "<span class="c31-cloze">to have sbd. do sth.</span>". To <span class="c32-cloze">make the request softer</span>, use <span class="c33-cloze">the negative</span>.</span> </p> <p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">   <span class="line">Examples:</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">è»Šã‚’<span class="c34-cloze">è²·ã£ã¦ã‚ã’ã‚‹</span>ã‚ˆã€‚"<span class="c35-cloze">Iâ€™ll give you the favor of buying a car.</span>" </span>   <span The disadvantage of the system is that it does not allow new talent to be merged with the experience and those with specialized skills cannot be promoted to the already crowded executive ranks. It also does not guarantee or even attempt to bring the "right person for the right job". The labor turnover rate in Japan is less than half the US level. The seniority-wage system can also be seen in Japanese government.&nbsp;Japanese parliament&nbsp;seats are usually filled with the older members from each party. </div> </div>

It is a very broad category for people in workforce, although it literally means people who are part of society.  The term is often used in contrast to gakusei (å­¦ç”Ÿ), which means students. The precise definition of ___ does not really exist. For example, how should we categorize shufu (ä¸»å©¦) i.e., housewives? Housewives may not be in the workforce, but they do often play important functions for society, such as raising children. Using the broader categorization, you could also say housewives are ___ (as well as students who really are part of the society).  What's interesting is that the term is often used to mean that people become first-class citizens only after they start working and join the labor force. In that sense, the usage of the term connotes that non-____ like students and housewives are second-class citizens. </div> </div>

âŸ®ã€€åå¤å±‹å¸‚ï¼ˆãªã”ã‚„ã—ï¼‰âŸ¯|âŸ®Nagoya (city)âŸ¯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The place that's famous for old roofs. I don't know why, but it's the city of Nagoya. Just associate the two things together and it'll be hard to forget (so long as you've heard of Nagoya before - if not, read up about it!).  </div><div class="sub all-b"> Nagoya&nbsp; is the largest city in the ChÅ«bu region of Japan. It is Japan's fourth-largest incorporated city and the third most populous urban area. Located on the Pacific coast on central Honshu, it is the capital of Aichi Prefecture and is one of Japan's major ports along with those of Tokyo, Osaka, Kobe, Yokohama, and Chiba. It is also the center of Japan's third-largest metropolitan region, known as the ChÅ«kyÅ metropolitan area. As of 1 October 2019, 2,327,557 people lived in the city, part of ChÅ«kyÅ metropolitan Area's 10.11 million people,[4] making it one of the 50 largest urban areas in the world.  In 1610, the warlord Tokugawa Ieyasu, a retainer of Oda Nobunaga, moved the capital of Owari Province from Kiyosu to Nagoya. This period saw the renovation of Nagoya Castle. Nagoya was proclaimed a city in 1889, during the Meiji Restoration; it became a major industrial hub for Japan. The traditional manufactures of timepieces, bicycles, and sewing machines were followed by the production of special steels, chemicals, oil, and petrochemicals, as the area's automobile, aviation, and shipbuilding industries flourished.[5] Nagoya was impacted by bombing from US air raids during World War II.  After the war, Nagoya developed into a major port and transport center. The Shinkansen high-speed line connecting Tokyo and Osaka converges on Nagoya. Nagoya is served by two airports: Chubu Centrair International Airport in nearby Tokoname, and Nagoya Airfield, home to Mitsubishi Aircraft Corporation. Nagoya remains an important center for the automotive, aviation, and ceramic industries, hosting the headquarters of Brother Industries, Ibanez, Lexus, and Toyota Tsusho, among others.  Nagoya is home to Nagoya University, the Nagoya Institute of Technology, and Nagoya City University. It is also the location of numerous cultural institutions, including the Tokugawa Art Museum, Atsuta Shrine, Higashiyama Zoo and Botanical Gardens, Aichi Arts Center, and Misono-za. Nagoya TV Tower is the oldest TV tower in Japan. </div> </div>

âŸ®ã€€è¼ªï¼ˆã‚ï¼‰:: 1 kanji âŸ¯|âŸ®Ring, wheel, loop, circleâŸ¯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. âŸ®ã€€å¹¸ç¦ï¼ˆã“ã†ãµãï¼‰ã®ã€€ç§‘å­¦ï¼ˆã‹ãŒãï¼‰âŸ¯|âŸ®___ formerly known as <span class="all-scr">The Institute for Research in in Human Happiness</span>, is a controversial new religious and spiritual movement, founded in Japan on 6 October 1986 by Ryuho Okawa, which has been characterized as a cult.âŸ¯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Happy Science worships a deity named El Cantare who they believe is the "Highest God of Earth, the Lord of all gods". They believe that the being was first born on Earth 330 million years ago and that it is the same entity that has been worshipped at different times as Elohim, Odin, Thoth, Ophealis (Osiris) Hermes and Shakyamuni Buddha, with Okawa himself as the current incarnation.[2][13]  </div><div class="sub all-b"> The group sold "spiritual vaccines" claimed to prevent and cure COVID-19, advertised virus-related blessings at rates from 100 to over US$400, and sold coronavirus-themed DVDs and CDs of Ryuho Okawa lecturing, which are claimed to boost immunity, as of April 2020. After initially defying physical distancing measures, it later closed its New York temple, and administered spiritual vaccines remotely.[19]  </div> </div>

âŸ®ã€€ç ´ï¼ˆã‚„ã¶ï¼‰ãâŸ¯|âŸ®tear, rip ã‚’âŸ¯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> in the case of ç ´, the ones with k as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, ã and ã‘ã‚‹)&nbsp; are (generally) semantically restricted to tearing, while those with r as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, ã‚‹ and ã‚Œã‚‹) can either have a tearing meaning, but also a meaning of breaking or defeating. The ones ending -u with one kana (that is, ã and ã‚‹) are intransitive (ãŒ), the ones ending -eru (that is, ã‘ã‚‹ and ã‚Œã‚‹) are transitive (ã‚’) </div> </div>

âŸ®ã€€ç”Ÿï¼ˆã„ï¼‰ã‘ã€€èŠ±ï¼ˆã°ãªï¼‰âŸ¯|âŸ®flower arrangementâŸ¯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> lit. making flowers come alive </div><div class="sub all-b"> The tradition dates back to Heian period, when floral offerings were made at altars. Later, flower arrangements were instead used to adorn the tokonoma (alcove) of a traditional Japanese home.  Ikebana reached its first zenith in the 16th century under the influence of Buddhist tea masters and has grown over the centuries, with numerous distinct schools extant today.  Ikebana is counted as one of the three classical Japanese arts of refinement, along with kÅdÅ for incense appreciation and chadÅ for tea and the tea ceremony. </div> </div>

âŸ®(æ—¥æœ¬ã®)ã€€ä¼çµ±èŠ¸èƒ½ï¼ˆã§ã‚“ã¨ã†ã’ã„ã®ã†ï¼‰âŸ¯|âŸ®c+;Japanese traditional performing arts&nbsp; is a general term for the arts and skills that have existed in Japan since ancient times. It refers to the tangible and intangible arts and crafts that have been passed down or discontinued in a particular form, either as an incidental part of the culture, entertainment, rituals, or festivals of a particular class or mass of people, or as a systematic part of an event. It includes poetry, music, dance, painting, crafts, and geido.&nbsp;âŸ¯

âŸ®ã€€å‡ºï¼ˆã ï¼‰ã— or ã€€å‡ºï¼ˆã ï¼‰ã€€æ±ï¼ˆã—ï¼‰ (cooking context)âŸ¯|âŸ®c+;) is a family of stocks used in Japanese cuisine. Dashi forms the base for miso soup, clear broth soup, noodle broth soup, and many simmering liquids to accentuate the savory flavor known as umami. The most common form of dashi is a simple broth made by heating water containing kombu (edible kelp) and kezurikatsuo (shavings of katsuobushi â€“ preserved, fermented skipjack tuna or bonito) to near-boiling, then straining the resultant liquid; dried anchovies or sardines may be substituted.âŸ¯

âŸ®ã€€äº¤éš›ï¼ˆã“ã†ã•ã„ï¼‰âŸ¯|âŸ®c+;association; relationship; dating, going out with someoneâŸ¯
âŸ®ã€€æ´åŠ©äº¤éš›ï¼ˆãˆã‚“ã˜ã‚‡ã“ã†ã•ã„ï¼‰ often shortened to ã€€æ´ï¼ˆãˆã‚“ï¼‰ã€€äº¤ï¼ˆã“ã†ï¼‰âŸ¯|âŸ®c+;dating with compensation (payments, financial support, etc.); schoolgirl prostitution.âŸ¯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > A 1997 poll in the Japanese TV Asahi program Asa Made Nama Terebi [ja] showed that 70 percent of respondents opposed enjo-kÅsai involving sexual interactions, while 30 percent approved of it.[6] Typically, it is perceived as an extension of Japan's growing focus on materialism, much of which is what critics claim is the cause of enjo-kÅsai. Critics worry that girls involved in enjo-kÅsai will grow up to be unfit wives and mothers. This perception arises from suspicions that when these girls are adults, they will quickly abandon their loyalties and commitments to their family for offers of money and material benefits.[6] However, certain feminist groups[which?] and critics regard enjo-kÅsai as an empowering way to "undermine patriarchal models of propriety used to evaluate and control women".[This quote needs a citation] Control over their bodies and means to support themselves is a new kind of independence for these girls. Good women in Japan are supposed to be sensible, modest, nurturing and respectful, yet girls participating in enjo-kÅsai clearly reject such virtues of female restraint and modesty in Japan. Feminists such as Chizuko Ueno point out that the accidental access of girls to this dating market was not a matter of ethics, but of probability.[6] Sooner or later, these girls and young women would, in a desire for financial independence, tap into this market for their own empowerment. However, Ueno points out that while engaging in enjo-kÅsai may appear beneficial for young women in the short term, it also reinforces patriarchal power structures by leaving the notion that women's bodies exist to serve male desire unchallenged.[7] </div> </div>
